title: No, Tom Cotton did not say this fake quote
subtitle: A fake viral meme is attributing a bizarre quote to Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.).
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
There is a lot being attributed lately to Sen. Tom Cotton, Republican freshman senator from Arkansas. He has been making headlines thanks to his open letter to the leaders of the Iranian regime warning against negotiating a nuclear deal with President Obama that Congress would not approve — an action that earned him the label “traitor” in a provocative Daily News front page image.

Given the whirlwind of media coverage Cotton has received lately, it is not surprising that a reader e-mailed us with the above image, found on Facebook. “Can this be true?” the reader asked. “Senator Cotton does seem like a bit of a loose cannon but this quote seem so unlikely.”

A quick search on social media outlets showed this same meme circulating among several left-leaning groups and accounts on Facebook and Twitter. There are at least two versions of the same “quote” being circulated.

This meme seems to be inspired by his maiden speech this week, during which he spoke about defense spending. After all, the “source” of the “quote” is cited as his floor speech. We tried to track down where it originated, but the trail through the abyss of social media memes ran cold.

Cotton was critical of current defense spending levels. He began his speech on that point: “The world is growing ever more dangerous and our defense spending is wholly inadequate to confront the danger.” He spoke on national security threats from Iran, North Korea and Russia. He described cuts made to each military branch, and urged Congress to restore the military budget to “reflect the threats we face” rather than voting on a budget that would define those threats.

There is no reference to prisons, or any specific government assistance programs — including “food stamps” — in his particular speech. But a popular news article that has been republished on left-leaning Web sites leading up to his speech were critical of his previous statements on food stamps (now formally known as Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP) and for calling Guantanamo Bay “one of our most effective counterterrorism tools.”

As for Medicare spending, Cotton did call for reducing spending in retirement and health care programs, which he called “the genuine driver of our long-term debt crisis.” Many budget experts have warned the the retirement of the Baby Boom generation will put budgetary pressure on Medicare and Social Security.

Cotton criticized the last major deficit-reduction deal, the Budget Control Act of 2011, for failing to confront the challenges faced by those programs and instead putting the burden of deficit reduction on annual discretionary spending, such as the defense budget. (Medicare and Social Security operate on automatic pilot, unless Congress takes the politically difficult step of altering benefits and fees.) Such a stance is catnip for liberal critics — witness this DailyKos article — but he certainly did not question the need for Medicare or suggest the program “nurtures the most dangerous elements of our society.”

Be careful what you see online. It takes seconds to make a meme. The more bizarre the quote, the quicker it gets retweeted, reblogged or reposted. While it contains elements of Cotton’s policy stances that his critics are not happy with, it is clear he never said this fake quote — certainly not in the particular speech cited in the image. The irresponsible image earns Four Pinocchios.
